entry.title: UMCD NKI group tractography eigenmodes
entry.summary:
Alternative versions: LabNotebook, nbviewer, slides, pdf

Overview¶

The following pages document and summarize investigations into the eigenmode structure of connectivity matrices from the NKI-Rockland dataset, as obtained from the USC multimodal connectivity database (UMCD). These analyses are one part of a larger ongoing project, including similar analyses of several other datasets, and so motivations, background theory, and analysis details are described here minimally. However, the full code for everything included in this report can be seen in the HTML version, which takes care of the lion's share of documentation requirements.

The primary aim of this notebook is to document the analysis steps (including complete code), and show the results as they stand at this point in time. As these are still somewhat exploratory analyses, the following sections contain a large amount of figures, which by necessity are only sparsely commented on. The 'summary of results' section below discusses some of the key points of interest, however there may well be further important patterns in the figures and data presented that I have not noticed or had time to comment on. So please feel free to feed back new observations and comments.

Notebook setup¶

Enable matlab in the notebook

%load_ext pymatbridge

Starting MATLAB on ZMQ socket ipc:///tmp/pymatbridge-b1af16d1-9f28-4f46-bfa7-3d2e1a2aa593
Send 'exit' command to kill the server
....................MATLAB started and connected!

Calico document tools

%%javascript
IPython.load_extensions('calico-spell-check',
                        'calico-document-tools','calico-cell-tools');

Define some variables

# define system-specific filepaths etc
%run ~/set_localenv_vars.py

# output dir
outdir = le['data_dir'] + '/notebooks/umcd_nki_group_eigenmodes'
!mkdir -p $outdir


# eigenmodes github repo
em_repo_dir  = le['code_dir'] + '/libraries_of_mine/github/eigenmodes'

# stuff for dropbox api
nb_name = 'umcd_nki_group_eigenmodes'

# stuff for analyses

nki_modified_matfile = outdir + '/nki_grp_modified_ctx_nosymm.mat'
nki_modified_matfile_github = em_repo_dir + '/data/nki_data/nki_grp_modified_ctx_nosymm.mat'
# (note: the above file is not the same as the one on /import/silo1/jgriffiths/Code; need to keep the 
#  two in sync via git commtts)

nki_dir = le['data_dir'] + '/UMCD/downloaded/NKI_Rockland'

nki_grp_aCM_textfile = nki_dir + '/NKI_dti_avg_connectivity_matrix_file.txt'
nki_grp_xyzs_textfile = nki_dir + '/NKI_dti_avg_region_xyz_centers_file.txt'
nki_grp_regionnames_textfile = nki_dir + '/NKI_dti_avg_region_names_full_file.txt'


# stuff for workdocs-cloudfiles

aws_key = 'drowssaperucesyreva'
aws_secret = '?teytidettopsuoyevah'

Importage

# Generic stuff

import os,sys

import pandas as pd
from pandas import DataFrame,concat

import numpy as np
from numpy import flipud,diag

from  scipy.io import loadmat,savemat


# Visualization stuff

%matplotlib inline
from matplotlib import cm,pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

from IPython.display import Image,clear_output,display as d


# Workdocs-cloudfiles stuff
sys.path.append(le['ipynb_workdocs_dir'])
from new_utils import nb_fig,cloudfiles_nb



# Eigenmodes github repo stuff

sys.path.append(em_repo_dir + '/utils')
from eigenmodes_utils import make_surf_montage,make_unihemi_scatter_montage,\
                             make_bihemi_scatter_montage,get_reordered_conmat,\
                             parse_nki_data

Set up aws workdocs-cloudfiles api

cnb = cloudfiles_nb('aws', [aws_key,aws_secret])
cnb.initialize_folder(nb_name)

Go to output directory

os.chdir(outdir)

%%matlab -i outdir
cd(outdir)

Ok, let's get cracking!

Background¶

We are interested in the extent to which the eigenmodes ( = eigenvectors ) of anatomical and connectivity matrices, as derived (in the present case) from diffusion-weighted MRI tractography, can be analyzed, modelled, and understood in terms of spherical harmonics. The reason for investigating this link is due to two relatively recent theoretical developments by Peter. The first of these is the propagator formulation for neural field theory (Robinson, 2012) which identifies the propagator term that determines the spatial spread of perturbations from baseline neural activity with the anatomical connectivity matrix. The second, more recent, development was the identification of solutions to the neural field equations on a single cortical hemisphere in terms of Laplace's equation. The eigenmodes of this system are therefore the spherical harmonics on the sphere, and their generalization to a curved cortical surface are the eigenmodes of the Laplace-Beltrami operator. The matrix-propagator formulation and the continuum field formulations are complementary, and their domains of applicability, validity of assumptions, and usefulness are independent but overlapping. Our aim in studying the spherical harmonic structure of anatomical connectivity matrices is to explore this region of overlap for the case of human brain connectivity at the meso-to-macroscopic scale.

Analysis Procedures¶

The analysis procedures in these investigations are fairly straightforward:

  1. Define/obtain a set of regions of interest (ROIs), xyz stereotaxic (e.g. MNI) coordinate locations for the centroids of these ROIs, and a connectivity matrix describing the (variously defined) strength of connection between each ROI pair.
  2. Find the modes (eigenvectors) of the connectivity matrix
    (sometimes we use matlab multiprecision toolbox to improve the accuracy of this step).
    Then, for the first handful (~5-10) modes:
  3. Visualize the eigenvector values for the first handful of modes as 3D scatter plots. To assist with these visualizations the structure, the data are binarized, setting all values below zero to -1 and all above zero to 1.
  4. Project the eigenvector values for each mode on to the (freesurfer) cortical surface mesh, where each surface vertex is assigned the eigenvector value for the ROI with the nearest centroid in Euclidean space (there are a few further details to this which I won't go into here). The result is something similar to nearest-neighbour interpolation.
  5. Use the vertex coordinates from the freesurfer-defined inflated (spherical) surfaces, whose vertices correspond one-to-one to the vertices of the folded cortical surface meshes, to project the eigenvector values (binarized, as with the scatter plots) on to a 2D 'worldmap'.
  6. Make visualizations for the three surface formats (folded cortex, sphere, and world map) together
  7. Visualize the eigenvalues as bar charts
  8. Visualize the eigenvector values as histograms
  9. Compute spherical harmonic coefficients from the eigenvector values on the inflated (spherical) surfaces
  10. Also where relevant, make visualizations of the original connectivity matrices
  11. Synthesize

All of the computationally significant steps above are carried out in matlab, using functions from the BrainDynamicsUSYD/eigenmodes github repository. Visualizations of the results are done with a combination of matlab and python code.

Prior to the matlab analyses, an initial data sorting and relabelling step is first carried out. This is explained in further detail (with complete code) below.

Summary of results¶

(Note that L-B mode topographies and spherical harmonic coefficients in these figures are computed elsewhere, and but the figures are included here for comparison purposes)

The principal figures in this document are the eigenmode topographies. The surface and scatter plot versions of these figures are complemenetary, and serve as sanity checks on each other.

Note: I think there is currently a bug in the right bihemispheric mode surface plots. The scatter plots look ok for these, but please ignore the bihemispheric modes data until this has been cleared up

The main result of interest is an apparent correspondence between both the eigenmode topographies and the spherical harmonic coefficients obtained from the aCM analyses described here, and those obtained from the Laplace-Beltrami (L-B) operator computed for the folded cortical surface.

The match in the topographies is most evident for the first four modes, with the first mode being global, and the next three one of three orthogonal 'splits' (lateral/medial, inferior-superior, posterior-anterior).

(0_0) 
f = outdir + '/LH_LB_vs_NKI_grp_aCM_mode_1to4_surfs_continuous.png'

label = ''
cap = ''

im = nb_fig(f,label,cap,cnb,size=(500,700),show_fignum=False)
d(im)
.

These patterns are clearest to see in the binarized topographies.

(0_0) 
f = outdir + '/LH_LB_vs_NKI_grp_aCM_mode_1to4_surfs_binary.png'

label = ''
cap = ''

im = nb_fig(f,label,cap,cnb,size=(500,700),show_fignum=False)
d(im)
.

For the spheric harmonic coefficients, the L-B operator modes for the inflated cortical surface show, as expected, a perfectly clean assignment of each of the the first 9 modes to the correct corresponding spherical harmonic coefficient, with values of zero for the non-corresponding coefficients.

(0_0) 
f = outdir + '/lh_inflated_lb_eig_sphcoeffs_P1.png'  

label = ''
cap = ''

im = nb_fig(f,label,cap,cnb,size=(500,700),show_fignum=False)
d(im)
.

The spherical harmonic coefficients for the folded cortical surface reproduce this pattern, but with a minor amount of 'noise', as indicated by small values for the non-corresponding coefficients, with greater noise for the finer (higher spatial freuqnecy) levels.

(0_0) 
f = outdir + '/lh_lb_eig_sphcoeffs_P1.png'


label = ''
cap = ''

im = nb_fig(f,label,cap,cnb,size=(500,700),show_fignum=False)
d(im)
.

Comparing these to the spherical harmonic coefficients for the surface-projected aCM modes, we see an impressive correspondence, with the dominant coefficient being reproduced at all except the fifth mode.

(0_0) 
f = outdir + '/nki_grp_aCM__nompt_unihemimodes_SH_coeffs_P1_LH.png'

label = ''
cap = ''

im = nb_fig(f,label,cap,cnb,size=(500,700),show_fignum=False)
d(im)
.

Whilst the scope for proper inferential statistics is limited here as these quantities are computed from group-averaged data, it is reasurring to see that this pattern is reproduced exactly in the right hemisphere also.

(0_0) 
f = outdir + '/nki_grp_aCM__nompt_unihemimodes_SH_coeffs_P1_RH.png'

label = ''
cap = ''

im = nb_fig(f,label,cap,cnb,size=(500,700),show_fignum=False)
d(im)
.

Sort and re-label data¶

We can't use the data directly as-is from the UMCD database, for a number of reasons:

  1. The labels are non-unique (i.e. multiple regions have the same label)
  2. We don't know the left-right ordering of the labels in advance.
  3. There are subcortical regions which we want to exclude in this analysis.

All of this is delegated to the parse_nki_data function, which we have imported from eigenmodes_utils.py.

This function returns a modified set of labels (with 1, 2, etc. suffixes to sort out the non-uniqueness problem), corresponding connectivity matrix and xyz coordinate arrays, and lists of which indices correspond to left and right hemisphere regions. The function removes subcortical, midbrain, brainstem, and cerebellar ROIs, and also removes any ROIs that are not present in both hemispheres (which is the case for some 3, 4 etc. ROIs).

conmat,labels,lh_inds,rh_inds,roi_xyz = parse_nki_data(nki_grp_regionnames_textfile,
                                                            nki_grp_aCM_textfile,
                                                            nki_grp_xyzs_textfile,
                                                            remove_noncortical=True,
                                                            make_hemi_symmetric=False,
                                                            sort_within_hemis=True)

Take a look at the parsed labels

lh_labels = [labels[l] for l in lh_inds]
rh_labels = [labels[r] for r in rh_inds]

d(pd.DataFrame([lh_inds,lh_labels,rh_inds,rh_labels],
             index=['lh indices', 'lh labels', 'rh indices', 'rh labels']).T)
lh indices lh labels rh indices rh labels

84 rows × 4 columns

Finally, save the modified data to a .mat file

matdict = {'nki_grp_aCM_conmat': conmat,
                 'nki_grp_aCM_labels': labels,
                 'nki_grp_aCM_lh_inds': lh_inds+1, # ADD 1 TO THE INDICES
                 'nki_grp_aCM_rh_inds': rh_inds+1, # ...COS THESE ARE FOR MATLAB
                 'nki_grp_aCM_roi_xyz': roi_xyz}

  

savemat(nki_modified_matfile,matdict)

savemat(nki_modified_matfile_github, matdict)

Run matlab analyses¶

Note: this takes a long time to run, but that is principally generating the figures.

To run the analyses without generating the figures, comment out all the lines which add the 'sfopt' structure into the 'opt' structure. This will run through the whole thing and spit out the .mat file results in a few minutes.

%%matlab --size 1200,500



% Setup
% ----------------------------------------------------------- 


% Set figure sizes etc.

% (this is also what is set by the matlab magic  '--size 1200,500' argument,
% but setting explicitly here so that the code will prdouce figures of the same size
% when run on different machines etc.)
plot_width = 1200; plot_height=500;
set(0, 'defaultfigurevisible', 'off')
set(0, 'defaultfigurepaperunits', 'inches')
set(0,'defaultfigureunits', 'inches')
set(0,'defaultfigurepaperposition', [0 0 int32(plot_width/150) int32(plot_height/150)])




   
   
% Define filepaths and input files

outdir = '/import/silo1/jgriffiths/Data/notebooks/umcd_nki_group_eigenmodes';
em_repo_dir = '/import/silo1/jgriffiths/Code/libraries_of_mine/github/eigenmodes';
mpt_dir = '/home/griffiths/Code/libraries_of_others/misc/multiprecision_toolbox'; % path when working  on lyceum
mpt_dir = '/import/suphys2/complex/MPT'; % path when working on other physics machines
addpath(genpath(em_repo_dir));
addpath(genpath(mpt_dir));


% Load setup variables from jg/data

nki_grp_modified_matfile = [em_repo_dir '/data/nki_data/nki_grp_modified_ctx_nosymm.mat'];
nkmd = load(nki_grp_modified_matfile);

palettes_file = [em_repo_dir  '/data/nki_data/palettes.mat'];
Ps = load(palettes_file);



% Specify default surface figure (sfopt) and general (opt) options structures

% binary yellow-green colour map
sfopt_gy_bin = struct('caxis', 'binarize',...
               'colormap', 'summer',...
               'close_figure', 1,...
               'save_tight', 0,...
               'add_colorbar',1,...
               'forcezero_contour', 1,...
               'save_subplots', 1, 'modes2do',1:10,...
               'png_outfile_tag', 'binarized_summer',...
               'title_stem', 'NKI Group-Average aCM data, unit-normalized, without mpt');

% continuous red-blue colour map, scaled by maximum value
sfopt_rb_mv = sfopt_gy_bin;
sfopt_rb_mv.colormap = Ps.divpal_260_15_99_57_1_120(:,1:3);
sfopt_rb_mv.png_outfile_tag = 'maxval_redblue';
sfopt_rb_mv.caxis = 'maxval';

% continuous red-blue colour map, scaled by fixed range of -0.15,0.15
sfopt_rb_fr = sfopt_gy_bin;
sfopt_rb_fr.colormap = Ps.divpal_260_15_99_57_1_120(:,1:3);
sfopt_rb_fr.png_outfile_tag = 'thr-0p15to0p15_redblue';
sfopt_rb_fr.caxis = [-0.15,0.15];


% binary red-blue colour map
sfopt_rb_bin = sfopt_gy_bin;
sfopt_rb_bin.colormap = Ps.divpal_260_15_99_57_1_120(:,1:3);
sfopt_rb_bin.png_outfile_tag = 'binarized_redblue';
sfopt_rb_bin.caxis = 'binarize';
    


opt_default = struct('eigenmodes_dir', em_repo_dir,...
                     'use_mpt', 0,...
                     'outfile_stem','REPLACE',...
                     'outdir', outdir,...
                     'use_hag2008_parc', 1,...
                     'sph_deg', 4);
    
    
    
% Final input variables for analyses

conmat = nkmd.nki_grp_aCM_conmat;
roi_xyz = nkmd.nki_grp_aCM_roi_xyz;
hemi_inds.lh = nkmd.nki_grp_aCM_lh_inds;
hemi_inds.rh = nkmd.nki_grp_aCM_rh_inds;


    
    
    
% Group aCM eigenmode analyses without multiprecision toolbox
% -------------------------------------------------------------------------------

% specify generic options

n_modes = 10;
hemi2do = {'lh', 'rh', 'bihemi'};
opt = opt_default;
opt.use_mpt = 0;
opt.outfile_stem = 'nki_grp_aCM__nompt';
    
% specify surface fig options
opt.sfopt{1} = sfopt_rb_bin;
%opt.sfopt{2} = sfopt_rb_fr;
%opt.sfopt{3} = sfopt_rb_mv;
%opt.sfopt{4} = sfopt_gy_bin;

opt.sfopt{1}.title_stem = 'NKI Group-Average aCM data, without mpt';
%opt.sfopt{2}.title_stem = opt.sfopt{2}.title_stem;
%opt.sfopt{3}.title_stem = opt.sfopt{3}.title_stem;
%opt.sfopt{4}.title_stem = opt.sfopt{4}.title_stem;


% Do it
close all
res.(opt.outfile_stem).aCM_dat = jg_compute_modes(conmat,roi_xyz,hemi2do,...
                                                  hemi_inds,n_modes,opt);    


% Group aCM eigenmode analyses with multiprecision toolbox
% ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

% specify generic options
n_modes = 10;
hemi2do = {'lh', 'rh', 'bihemi'};
opt = opt_default;
opt.use_mpt = 1;
opt.outfile_stem = 'nki_grp_aCM__mpt';
    
% specify surface fig options
%opt.sfopt{1} = sfopt_rb_bin;
%opt.sfopt{2} = sfopt_rb_mv;
%opt.sfopt{3} = sfopt_rb_fr;
%opt.sfopt{4} = sfopt_gy_bin;

%opt.sfopt{1}.title_stem = 'NKI Group-Average aCM data, with mpt';
%opt.sfopt{2}.title_stem = opt.sfopt{2}.title_stem;
%opt.sfopt{3}.title_stem = opt.sfopt{3}.title_stem;
%opt.sfopt{4}.title_stem = opt.sfopt{4}.title_stem;


% Do it
close all
res.(opt.outfile_stem).aCM_dat = jg_compute_modes(conmat,roi_xyz,hemi2do,...
                                                  hemi_inds,n_modes,opt);

(note: eigenmodes colour palettes file copied to github repo from eigenmodes_colour_palettes notebook)

Load in results¶

This is required for most of the sections below

# the above jg_compute_modes.m calls outputs the following  ' _data.mat' files:
res_files = {'mpt':   outdir + '/nki_grp_aCM__mpt_data.mat',
                   'nompt': outdir + '/nki_grp_aCM__nompt_data.mat'}
 
# load in the .mat files
res_mats = {k: loadmat(v, squeeze_me=True,struct_as_record=False)['modecomps']  for k,v in res_files.items()}

Connectivity matrices¶

These are included really just for completeness / sanity check. They don't show anything of particular relevance here. Note that the reason why it is hard to see much in them is because the parcellation size is pretty dense (500 nodes per hemisphere); connectivity matrices from coarser parcellations are a little easier to eyeball.

dat = np.log1p(res_mats['nompt'].bihemi.dat)

# with colourbar
f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__nompt_conmat_cbar.png' % outdir
    
fig, ax = plt.subplots()#figsize=(10,10))
sns.heatmap(dat, linewidths=0, square=True, ax=ax,
            xticklabels=False, yticklabels=False)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig(f, bbox_inches='tight',dpi=600)
plt.close()
  
  
# without colourbar
f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__nompt_conmat_nocbar.png' %outdir
fig, ax = plt.subplots()#figsize=(10,10))
sns.heatmap(dat, linewidths=0, square=True, ax=ax,
            xticklabels=False, yticklabels=False,cbar=False)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig(f, bbox_inches='tight',dpi=600)
plt.close()
(0_0) 
f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__nompt_conmat_cbar.png' %outdir
label = ''
cap = ''
#fignum = '4.1'
im = nb_fig(f,label,cap,cnb,size=(500,700),show_fignum=False)#,upload_file=False)
d(im)
.

The 'best' visualizations of the matrices are actually obtained when we revisit the 'parse_nki_data' function used above, and set the 'make_hemi_symmetric' argument to True. This returns matrices with identical nodes in each hemisphere, sorted first acocrding to hemisphere, and then with the same sorting order within hemispheres.

conmat_symm,labels_symm,lh_inds_symm,rh_inds_symm,roi_xyz_symm = parse_nki_data(nki_grp_regionnames_textfile,
                                                            nki_grp_aCM_textfile,
                                                            nki_grp_xyzs_textfile,
                                                            remove_noncortical=True,
                                                            make_hemi_symmetric=True)# False)


dat = np.log1p(conmat_symm)

f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM_conmat_symm_cbar.png' % outdir    

fig, ax = plt.subplots()#figsize=(10,10))
sns.heatmap(dat, linewidths=0, square=True, ax=ax,
            xticklabels=False, yticklabels=False)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig(f, bbox_inches='tight',dpi=600)
plt.close()
(0_0) 
label = ''
cap = ''
#fignum = '4.1'
im = nb_fig(f,label,cap,cnb,size=(500,700),show_fignum=False)#,upload_file=False)
d(im)
.

This would have been the preferential data to do the analyses with, but I have done that and the results aren't so good as not removing the non-symmetric regions. There isn't a fundamental reigon for doing that, it just would be cleaner in a sense, and gives nicer matrices for plotting. It removes around 40 data points however, which may be the reason for the results looking less good.

Probably some kind of manual ordering can be constructed for the non-symmetric matrices we are using here, which will make them look

more or less like the one above. It's just that that one was easier to achieve automatically

Mode topographies¶

Comparison point: Laplace-Beltrami eigenmodes for left hemisphere cortical surface¶

Note the three key patterns: posterior/anterior split (mode 2), inferior-superior split (mode 3), and lateral/medial split, and/or 'stripe down the middle' (mode 4).

(A more comprehensive evaluation of these patterns is given in a separate notebook).

(0_0) 
f = '%s/LH_LB_eigs_1to4.png' %outdir
label = ''
cap = ''
im = nb_fig(f,label,cap,cnb,size=(500,700),show_fignum=False)
d(im)
.

(side comment on this image: it is interesting that the 2nd and 3rd modes here look like mirror images in the worldmap (as expected for 2nd and 3rd spherical harmonics), but on the brain topographies they look (more-or-less?) like cuts down the canonical (orthogonal?) anterio-posterior/caudal/rostram and inferior/superior/dorsal-ventral planes. Does this mean anything interesting?? Would probably help with the intuitions to see movies of the modes and the worldmaps rotated in the x y and z directions...)

Make surface figure and scatter plot montages¶

 
doscatters=True# False#True
dosurfaces=False# True # False


# blue-red colour palette
divpal_260_15_99_57_1_120 = sns.diverging_palette(h_neg=260,h_pos=15,s=99,l=57,sep=2,
                                                  n=120,as_cmap=True)
brcmap=divpal_260_15_99_57_1_120

nes = 10
mks = 150

# need to test out the crops manually before running the whole thing


# these are the crops that work right when I run the matlab figure generation code in 'normal ' matlab
#crops = {'ctp': 55, 'cbp': 70, 'cts': 65, 'cbs': 70, # crop top/bottom pial/sphere
#         'clp': 160, 'crp': 100, 'cls': 305, 'crs': 260, #crop left/right pial/sphere
#        'ctw': 40, 'cbw': 40, 'ctb': 1, 'cbb': 1, # crop top/bottom wmap/colorbar
#        'clw': 160, 'crw': 115, 'clb': 10, 'crb': 60} # crop left/right wmap/colorbar

# the ones that work best for when running matlab inside the notebook with pymatbridge are the 
# defaults in make_surf_montage
# (for that, set crops=None, or just don't supply the crops argument in the function calls)
 # (...also specifying explicitly here, with minor modification)
crops = {'ctp': 55, 'cbp': 70, 'cts': 60, 'cbs': 70, # crop top/bottom pial/sphere
              'clp': 350, 'crp': 300, 'cls': 445, 'crs': 400, #crop left/right pial/sphere
              'ctw': 40, 'cbw': 40, 'ctb': 1, 'cbb': 1, # crop top/bottom wmap/colorbar
              'clw': 180, 'crw': 180, 'clb': 10, 'crb': 60} # crop left/right wmap/colorbar
    
    
for k,v in  res_mats.items(): # [res_mats.items()[1]]:
        
        
    print '\n\nloading %s data...' %k
    dat = v
    
    inds_lh = dat.lh.hemi_inds.lh-1
    roi_xyz_lh = dat.lh.roi_xyz[inds_lh,:]
    
    if 'nompt' in k:
      V_lh = dat.lh.V
      V_rh = dat.rh.V
      V_bihemi = dat.bihemi.V
    else: 
      V_lh = dat.lh.V_dp
      V_rh = dat.rh.V_dp
      V_bihemi = dat.bihemi.V_dp

        
    V_bin_lh = V_lh.copy()
    V_bin_lh[V_lh<0] = -1
    V_bin_lh[V_lh>0] = 1

    inds_rh = dat.rh.hemi_inds.rh-1
    roi_xyz_rh = dat.rh.roi_xyz[inds_rh,:]
    V_bin_rh = V_rh.copy()
    V_bin_rh[V_rh<0] = -1
    V_bin_rh[V_rh>0] = 1

    roi_xyz_bihemi = dat.bihemi.roi_xyz
    V_bin_bihemi = V_bihemi.copy()
    V_bin_bihemi[V_bihemi<0] = -1
    V_bin_bihemi[V_bihemi>0] = 1    
  
    
    
    for unibi in ['unihemi', 'bihemi']:
        
        
        
    
      # Scatter plots
      # ==============
    
      if doscatters:
            
        print '\nmaking %s scatter plots...' %(unibi)
        
        modes2do = [1,2,3,4]
        f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__%s_%smodes_binarized_redblue_scatter_modes1to4.png' %(outdir,k,unibi)
        if unibi == 'unihemi':
          make_unihemi_scatter_montage(roi_xyz_lh,roi_xyz_rh,V_bin_lh,V_bin_rh,modes2do,f,cmap=brcmap,markersize=mks)
        elif unibi == 'bihemi':
          make_bihemi_scatter_montage(roi_xyz_bihemi,V_bin_bihemi,modes2do,f,cmap=brcmap,markersize=mks)
        
        modes2do = [5,6,7,8,9]
        f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__%s_%smodes_binarized_redblue_scatter_modes5to9.png' %(outdir,k,unibi)
        if unibi == 'unihemi':
          make_unihemi_scatter_montage(roi_xyz_lh,roi_xyz_rh,V_bin_lh,V_bin_rh,modes2do,f,cmap=brcmap,markersize=mks)
        elif unibi == 'bihemi':
          make_bihemi_scatter_montage(roi_xyz_bihemi,V_bin_bihemi,modes2do,f,cmap=brcmap,markersize=mks)
        
        
        
      # Surface figures
      # ================
    
      if dosurfaces:
            
                
        print '\nmaking %s surface figs...' %(unibi)
                    
        # make montages  
     
        astr = 'nki_grp_aCM__%s_%smodes_lh_binarized_redblue' %(k,unibi)
  
        for e_it, e in enumerate(range(nes)):
       
          lh_surfoutfile = '%s/%s_mode%s_montage_nocbar.png' %(outdir,astr,e+1)
        
          f1= '%s/%s_mode%s_pial_latview.png' %(outdir,astr,e+1)
          f2= '%s/%s_mode%s_sphere_latview.png' %(outdir,astr,e+1)
          f3= '%s/%s_mode%s_sphere_medview.png' %(outdir,astr,e+1)
          f4= '%s/%s_mode%s_pial_medview.png' %(outdir,astr,e+1)
          f5= '%s/%s_mode%s_wmap.png' %(outdir,astr,e+1)
          f6= '%s/%s_mode%s_cbar.png' %(outdir,astr,e+1)

        
          lh_fs = [f1,f2,f3,f4,f5,f6]
          make_surf_montage(lh_fs,lh_surfoutfile,closefig=True,include_cbar=False,crops=crops)           
        
          rh_surfoutfile = lh_surfoutfile.replace('lh', 'rh')
          rh_fs = [r.replace('lh', 'rh') for r in lh_fs] 
          make_surf_montage(rh_fs,rh_surfoutfile,closefig=True,include_cbar=False,crops=crops)
                
        
        # modes 1-4 figure
        
        eigs = [1,2,3,4]
        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=len(eigs),ncols=2,figsize=(10,8))

        for e_it, e in enumerate(eigs):
    
          ax[e_it,0].imshow(plt.imread('%s/%s_mode%s_montage_nocbar.png' %(outdir,astr,e)))
          ax[e_it,0].axis('off')  
          ax[e_it,0].set_title('%s mode %s, LH' %(unibi,e), fontsize=15)
    
          ax[e_it,1].imshow(plt.imread('%s/%s_mode%s_montage_nocbar.png' %(outdir,
                                                                   astr.replace('lh', 'rh'),e)))
          ax[e_it,1].axis('off')  
          ax[e_it,1].set_title('%s mode %s, RH' %(unibi,e), fontsize=15)

        plt.tight_layout()
    
        f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__%s_%smodes_binarized_redblue_surf_modes1to4.png' %(outdir,k,unibi)
        plt.savefig(f, bbox_inches='tight')            
        plt.close()
    
    
        # modes 5-9 figure
    
        eigs = [5,6,7,8,9]
        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=len(eigs),ncols=2,figsize=(10,10))
    
        for e_it, e in enumerate(eigs):
    
          ax[e_it,0].imshow(plt.imread('%s/%s_mode%s_montage_nocbar.png' %(outdir,astr,e)))
          ax[e_it,0].axis('off')  
          ax[e_it,0].set_title('%s mode %s, LH' %(unibi,e), fontsize=15)
    
          ax[e_it,1].imshow(plt.imread('%s/%s_mode%s_montage_nocbar.png' %(outdir,
                                                                   astr.replace('lh', 'rh'),e)))
          ax[e_it,1].axis('off')  
          ax[e_it,1].set_title('%s mode %s, RH' %(unibi,e), fontsize=15)

        plt.tight_layout()
    
        f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__%s_%smodes_binarized_redblue_surf_modes5to9.png' %(outdir,k,unibi)
        plt.savefig(f, bbox_inches='tight')            
        plt.close()

Unihemispheric aCM eigenmode topographies¶

Just looking at these without multiprecision toolbox (see appendix for figures computed with multiprecision toolbox)

Modes 1-4 observations:

  • pattern is highly consistent between two hemispheres (allowing for a) several sign flaps, and b) swapping order of modes 3 and 4)
  • and highly similar to first few L-B mode topographies:
    • global first mode
    • next three show, roughly, orthogonal splits along inferior-superior/dorsal-ventral, anterior-posterior/rostral-caudal, and medial-lateral planes
    • the medial-lateral split 'reaches round the front and back' a little in LH mode 4, and round the top and bottom in the RH equivalent mode 3)

Modes 5-9 observations

  • LH mode 5 and RH mode 5 have similar topographies (esp on scatter plots), but worldmaps don't look similar
  • LH mode 5 and RH mode 6 have similar looking worldmaps, althugh topographies don't look all that similar (look more similar in scatter plots)
  • Can see higher spatial frequency 'stripes' easiest in scatter plots for e.g. LH modes 7,8,9

Bihemispheric aCM eigenmode topographies¶

Bihemi modes 1-4 observations

  • (focusing on scatter plots...)
  • global bihemi mode 1
  • L-R split for mode 2
  • Modes 3 and 4 are symmetric; i.e. same in each hemisphere
  • Modes 3 and 4 could be described as inferior-superior and medial-lateral splits, although really they're something a bit different
  • Structure of the split in modes 3 and 4 looks liek a 'wedge'; but the wedge is pointed in different directions for each (so can be seen from different planes)

.

Bihemi modes 5-9 observations

  • (Again, focusing on scatter plots)
  • Modes 5 to 9 are also, more or less, symmetric between hemispheres
  • Patterns mostly correspond to 'stripes' or 'quadrants'

Eigenvector Histograms¶

eig_xlims = [-0.00005,0.00005]
eig_bins = np.linspace(eig_xlims[0],eig_xlims[1],500)


for k,v in res_mats.items():
    
      
    dat = v #  res_mats['nki_%s_aCM_%s' %(v,mp)] 
              
    for unibi in ['unihemi', 'bihemi']:

        
      # Unihemispheric modes
      # --------------------
        
      if unibi == 'unihemi':

        if k == 'mpt':
          lh_evecs = DataFrame(np.fliplr(dat.lh.V_dp)).copy()
          rh_evecs = DataFrame(np.fliplr(dat.rh.V_dp)).copy()
        elif k == 'nompt':
          lh_evecs = DataFrame(np.fliplr(dat.lh.V)).copy()
          rh_evecs = DataFrame(np.fliplr(dat.rh.V)).copy()

        

        # Modes 1-4
        
        f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__%s_%smodes_eigenvector_histograms_modes1to4.png' %(outdir,k,unibi)
        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=4,ncols=2, figsize=(10,8))
        
        for n_it,n in enumerate([0,1,2,3]):
          #lh_evecs[n].plot(kind='hist',bins=eig_bins,alpha=0.6,ax=ax[n_it,0])
          #rh_evecs[n].plot(kind='hist',bins=eig_bins,alpha=0.6,ax=ax[n_it,1])
          lh_evecs[n].plot(kind='hist',alpha=0.6,ax=ax[n_it,0],bins=100)
          rh_evecs[n].plot(kind='hist',alpha=0.6,ax=ax[n_it,1],bins=100)            
          ax[n_it,0].set_title('LH mode %s' %(n+1))            
          ax[n_it,1].set_title('RH mode %s' %(n+1))            
            
        #for a in ax.ravel(): a.set_xlim(eig_xlims); a.set_xlabel('');         
        for a in ax.ravel(): a.set_xlabel('');  #a.set_xlim(eig_xlims);   
        plt.tight_layout()
        plt.savefig(f,bbox_inches='tight')
        plt.close()

            
            
        # Modes 5-9
        
        f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__%s_%smodes_eigenvector_histograms_modes5to9.png' %(outdir,k,unibi)
        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=5,ncols=2, figsize=(10,10))
        
        for n_it,n in enumerate([4,5,6,7,8]):
          #lh_evecs[n].plot(kind='hist',bins=eig_bins,alpha=0.6,ax=ax[n_it,0])
          #rh_evecs[n].plot(kind='hist',bins=eig_bins,alpha=0.6,ax=ax[n_it,1])
          lh_evecs[n].plot(kind='hist',alpha=0.6,ax=ax[n_it,0],bins=100)
          rh_evecs[n].plot(kind='hist',alpha=0.6,ax=ax[n_it,1],bins=100)            
            
          ax[n_it,0].set_title('LH mode %s' %(n+1))            
          ax[n_it,1].set_title('RH mode %s' %(n+1))           
            
          
        #for a in ax.ravel(): a.set_xlim(eig_xlims); a.set_xlabel('');     
        for a in ax.ravel(): a.set_xlabel('');  #a.set_xlim(eig_xlims);   
            
        plt.tight_layout()
        plt.savefig(f,bbox_inches='tight')
        plt.close()
        
        
            
            
      # Bihemispheric modes
      # -------------------
            
            
      elif unibi == 'bihemi':
        if k == 'mpt':        
          bihemi_evecs = DataFrame(np.fliplr(dat.bihemi.V_dp)).copy()
        elif k == 'nompt':
          bihemi_evecs = DataFrame(np.fliplr(dat.bihemi.V)).copy()
     

        # Modes 1-4
        
        
        f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__%s_%smodes_eigenvector_histograms_modes1to4.png' %(outdir,k,unibi)
        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=4,ncols=1, figsize=(10,8))
        
        for n_it,n in enumerate([0,1,2,3]):
          #bihemi_evecs[n].plot(kind='hist',bins=eig_bins,alpha=0.6,ax=ax[n_it])
          bihemi_evecs[n].plot(kind='hist',bins=100,alpha=0.6,ax=ax[n_it])
          ax[n_it].set_title('Bihemi mode %s' %(n+1))            

        # for a in ax.ravel(): a.set_xlim(eig_xlims); a.set_xlabel('');         
        for a in ax.ravel(): a.set_xlabel('');  #a.set_xlim(eig_xlims);   
                    
        plt.tight_layout()
        plt.savefig(f,bbox_inches='tight')
        plt.close()

        
        # Modes 5-9
        
        f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__%s_%smodes_eigenvector_histograms_modes5to9.png' %(outdir,k,unibi)
        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=5,ncols=1, figsize=(10,10))
        
        for n_it,n in enumerate([4,5,6,7,8]):
          bihemi_evecs[n].plot(kind='hist',alpha=0.6,ax=ax[n_it],bins=100)
          ax[n_it].set_title('Bihemi mode %s' %(n+1))            
          
        for a in ax.ravel(): a.set_xlabel('');  #a.set_xlim(eig_xlims);          
            
        plt.tight_layout()
        plt.savefig(f,bbox_inches='tight')
        plt.close()

Eigenvalues¶

data = res_mats['nompt']

Convert the eigenvalue matrices to 1-D vectors and place in pandas dataframe for easy manipulation and `visualization

lh_evals = DataFrame(flipud(diag(data.lh.D)), columns=['LH']).copy()
rh_evals = DataFrame(flipud(diag(data.rh.D)), columns=['RH']).copy()
bihemi_evals = DataFrame(flipud(diag(data.bihemi.D)), columns=['Bihemi']).copy()

all_evals = concat([lh_evals,rh_evals,bihemi_evals], axis=1)

all_evals.index = all_evals.index+1
all_evals.index.names = ['Eig #']

List the first 9 eigenvalues from the three decompositions

d(all_evals.ix[0:9])
LH RH Bihemi
Eig #
1 6915.704038 7551.744059 8348.389968

5 2584.200935 2674.339468 4535.678329
6 2271.007948 2462.663753 3945.085308
7 2182.053767 2243.843388 3512.190597
8 1509.979466 2076.165803 3372.842960

Spherical Harmonic Coefficients¶

Make spherical harmonic coefficient 'P1' figures¶

for k,v in res_mats.items():
    dat = v
    
    for unibi in ['unihemi', 'bihemi']:
        if unibi == 'unihemi':
            df_P1_lh = pd.DataFrame(dat.lh.S.P1)  
            df_P1_rh = pd.DataFrame(dat.rh.S.P1)  
        elif unibi == 'bihemi':
            df_P1_lh = pd.DataFrame(dat.bihemi.S_lh.P1)  
            df_P1_rh = pd.DataFrame(dat.bihemi.S_rh.P1)  
        f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__%s_%smodes_SH_coeffs_P1_LH.png' %(outdir,k,unibi)
        
        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=1,ncols=1,figsize=(12,4))
        
        df_P1_lh_norm = df_P1_lh/df_P1_lh.sum()
        df_P1_lh_norm.T.plot(kind='bar',ax=ax, legend=True,
                           title='nki grp aCM %s %s eigenmode SH coeffs P1 LH'%(k,unibi))
        ax.legend(['', 0,1,2,3,4],loc='upper right',title='L',fontsize=15)
        ax.set_xlabel('M', fontsize=15)
        
        plt.tight_layout()
   
        plt.savefig(f, bbox_inches='tight')
   
        plt.close()            
      

        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=1,ncols=1,figsize=(12,4))
        
        f = '%s/nki_grp_aCM__%s_%smodes_SH_coeffs_P1_RH.png' %(outdir,k,unibi)
        
        df_P1_rh_norm = df_P1_rh/df_P1_rh.sum()
        df_P1_rh_norm.T.plot(kind='bar',ax=ax, legend=True,
                           title='nki grp aCM %s %s aCM eigenmode SH coeffs P1 RH'%(k,unibi))
        ax.legend(['', 0,1,2,3,4],loc='upper right',title='L',fontsize=15)
        ax.set_xlabel('M', fontsize=15)

        plt.tight_layout()
        plt.savefig(f, bbox_inches='tight')

        plt.close()
